reviewText: I (luckily) only know one distant acquaintance with Lyme disease (knock on wood) and yet found this documentary very interesting & relevant.If anyone you care about has Lyme, then you must see this!If anyone you care about has Alzheimer's, ALS (Lou Gehrig), multiple sclerosis, Parkinsonism, or any other disease without a known causative agent, then you really, really ought to watch this and consider whether or not they might actually have Lyme. (and also consider GMO foods).If you vote, or if you care about our medical system, then you really ought to watch this to understand why the US medical system is so totally broken and corrupted that the only realistic fix (in my opinion) is European-style nationalized health care.As someone said herein, Lyme is not only a biological disease but also a political and economic disease.Watch this!
summary: Relevant to everyone, with or without Lyme

reviewText: My husband is a fly fisherman, so he is often out in the woods, going through brush.  He's often concerned about getting Lyme Disease so this put us both at ease to know what to look for but also to advocate for oneself when dealing with the medical community.  VERY enlightening film.

reviewText: After seeing this film, I will be far more aware of my surroundings while on hikes etc.  I have not really even heard of lyme disease before this movie, and none of the physicians that I have been to have ever suggested testing me for the disease.  I live in the San Francisco Bay Area, and I know there are ticks around, and I even remember being bitten by one when I was younger.  This movie has compelled me to want to get a test for this disease, as I know of a friend of mine that was also recently diagnosed with the disease, after having a set of routine health tests.  This movie is very eye opening and equally scary.  It makes me hate insurance companies more than I already do, which is a lot.

reviewText: A must-see documentary, which reveals previously unknown facts about Lyme disease.  Interviews with people who suffer from it and information about the source of the disease.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a very riveting and important documentary about bacterial Lyme Disease, which is spread by certain ticks as vectors. The disease itself is quite prevalent and spreading around the world, and it could affect you and your family. Lyme can affect people differently, and there is much consternation and greedy politics involved in whether to treat patients, especially when health insurance companies are involved (of course). Many who actually do suffer from this affliction are not taken seriously, and are denied treatment coverage by their heartless and greedy insurance companies. All in all, the film is a very informative and humbling glimpse into the lives of those afflicted with Lyme Disease, and a scathing indictment of how narrow minded and greedy some of our health institutions have become here in the United States. Don't miss this one!
summary: A 'must see' film!  Lyme Disease is spreading widely.

reviewText: Just as AIDS got the attention of the goverment, the medical field and the whole world in the early 80's, no one is going to pay attention to this disease until a bunch of angry parents, sisters, brothers, and friends march on Washington and demand transparency.One of my friend's step-daughters suffered with Lyme disease for years.  She finally took her own life about two years ago.  She was a young Mom, but even her love for her baby could not save her.  This is a national embarrassment, and we need to get it out from under the rug and get serious about diagnosing and treating these people properly.
summary: We need to start a movement

reviewText: I have Lyme disease and I thought I was alone. Only minutes into the movie I started crying because right there in front of me was another person whom was having all of the same problems I was! It was a relief to know I am not alone and the movie depicts the disease perfectly. Even though I had read every book out there on Lyme, I was surprised to learn that it is associated with so many other well known diseases, such as Parkinsons, Alzheimer's, ALS, etc. If you or anyone you care about has been diagnosed with Lyme disease, this movie is a real eye opener and a must see! I would give it more than 5 stars if I could.

reviewText: It's really sad how far we have gotten away from objective reporting in modern documentaries.  This was just another example of how selective reporting can be used to push the political agenda of one side of a complicated issue.  It's funny that there wasn't a single mention of C. dif or any of the other significant health complications related to the over prescription of antibiotics.  Medicine is about using proven scientific studies to make decisions about how to treat people in a way that results in the highest probability of benefit with the lowest probability or harm.  Some of the points in the documentary may well be valid but they lose all credibility due to the biased way in which the producers present only some of the information and spin the issue to support their idiotic theory of conspiracy.

reviewText: 2009NR: Watching this video in 2011 reminded me of a colleague's daughter who suffered from lyme disease for nearly a year in 2009 before finally being diagnosed by a thorough doctor at Saint Joseph's hospital (Tampa, FL).This documentary is like a video of her story. The unexplained pain, the confusion, the missed school and work days visiting doctors who weren't aptly informed about the real number of misdiagnosed cases. Not to mention the doctors who simply told her 'it's all in your head'.Watch this film, not because it's popular today, but because it may save someone you love lot's of unnecessary pain and suffering.Enjoy. 4x MFJLabs
summary: "We Don't Know What's Wrong With You"

reviewText: "Under Our Skin" is a powerfully made film that tells the much needed story about the misdiagnosis and often lack of diagnosis of Lyme Disease. Some of the specific anecdotes here - the woman, for example, who is apparently told by her doctor that the reasons for her mystery illness is purely psychological and likely the result of her not getting attention from men - are so distressing they are almost too much to take. What this film does well, it does very well - it puts a face to this still mysterious but potentially devastating illness. It also fully and openly exposes audiences to the depth of pain and suffering this disease has caused people and should be viewed by anyone who dismisses Lyme as some sort of fad disease. However, I personally think it is worth considering the fact that illnesses and conditions - everything from pellagra to Legionnaire's to autism to AIDS to drug addiction - are often misunderstood for years before the proper treatment is discovered, if at all. And in that space and time where a cure is elusive there will always be unscrupulous and/or wrong-headed doctors there to exploit a market of desperate and fearful people. This is just a fact of history and a fact of life. In watching this film and the occasionally hagiographic light it casts on outlier doctors challenging the inadequate orthodoxy of today's treatment, I thought to myself, if 15 years from now one of these doctors is found to have peddled ineffective and even harmful treatments to  patients it would not surprise me.Like anything else, buyer beware.

reviewText: Wow, simply, wow.This is an amazing video about the interplay between conventional medicine and it's rigid standards; doctors who still hold true to their Hippocratic oath; and dirty politics of healthcare.If you ever had a medical condition -- or faced appalling medicine first hand (like I did with military medicine back in the 80s) -- you'll understand in getting well again isn't just mind over matter, there's other roadblocks that has nothing to do with you itself...it's also the "system" that can beat you down.Personally, I can relate to those in this video when an auto accident nearly killed me. A routine, patch you up and go home situation, turned into a life-or-death 1 month hospitalization that horror stories are made from and years of recovery. It scars you for life, but it makes you tougher as a human being. Those in this video are survivors, both physically and psychologically and need to be commended. The comment in the video of the lady taking 4hrs to get to one side of the house to another (showing her determination of her dignity and strength), I relate to trying to walk again, starting with using my toes to push a wheelchair (loss 80% muscle tone in my leg). Or to even eat with boarded up hands, and trying to suck Jello threw a straw (the staff sure wasn't going to help feed me anyway...don't you love hospitals that can deliver a food tray in ICU, but you only have 2 fingers on each hand to use and they won't hold a fork even???).Yeah, that's the survivors in this video, hero/ines of medicine. I admire everyone one of them of learning their personal story in combating something that suppose to be so easy to treat, yet "the system" can't/won't treat properly. The "system" is more concerned about preserving their back sides.Same BS they did with Halton Arp in Astrophysics too, they just do with MDs, pulling their licenses to protect their self-interests and reputations. The docs here aren't quacks, they use conventional medicine and found long-term antibiotics works for these patients. Simple deduction medicine, just like off-label prescribing of medications to treat conditions. That's what these doctors are doing, not selling snake oil. No fringe. No "alternative" herbal treatments. Antibiotics over time -- and the politics in this mess? Do so, and we'll target the doctors.Is this another Tuskeegee medical experiment (same syphilis background. Trying to complete what wasn't complete, yet)? -_-Any fighter out there who came back off the mat should watch this video. It's inspirational, educational and shows the will and spirit of those determined to do what is right. Here, that's actually living again./Salute.
summary: Why Medicine and Politics Don't Mix
Title: N/A

reviewText: We live in an area of endemic Lyme and other rikettsial diseases.  Lyme is difficult to diagnose, but the presence of ticks/tick bits is pretty definitive.  Many physicians don't have the time to study all of the areas of medicine in an ongoing fashion and rely heavily on professional societies/studies.  And sometimes those societies and studies are either inadequate or just wrong.  this DVD follows several people who struggled with the disease and even more frustrating, with the profession that often did not take them seriously.As a retired mid-level provider (nurse practitioner) I am more than familiar with the difficulties of really hearing what the patient is telling us and following up in an ethical and effective manner.  The time committment for the practitioner is often overwhelming, but it is a necessary part of effective, ethical practice.I have good friends whose experience validates those on this DVD, and I have had my own experience of being blown off by my primary care physician, "because the studies say you don't need to . . . " (fill in the blanks).  this DVD also addresses the nature of some of the studies.While things are improving and one is seeing more and more information on Lyme in the public venue, there's a long way to go.  this DVD may keep you awake at night.
Title: N/A
